title: Teachers Union Chief Defends the L.A. Strike
summary: Randi Weingarten says the entire six-day strike was about children's needs.. Regarding Jason Riley's "Teachers Unions Don't Really Strike for 'the Kids'" (Jan. 23): It's hard to argue that teachers in Los Angeles didn't care about kids when the entire six-day strike was about children's needs. That's why the agreement in L.A., which was ratified Jan. 22, is full of provisions to that effect: a school nurse in every school, every day; more counselors; a commitment to more community schools that provide wraparound services. As any neutral observer could see-and contrary to Mr. Riley's views that this was all about teacher salaries-the basics of the negotiated 6% salary increase for educators was offered by management before the strike even began.

title: Index Funds Are Cheap But Not Always Best
summary: I'd say index investing harms investors much more than sales charges do. Contrary to Bogle's proclamation, you do get what you pay for.. Burton Malkiel details some of "The Secrets of Jack Bogle's Investment Success" (op-ed, Jan. 18). There are others. Funds like Vanguard's flagship S&P 500 index fund don't research their investments. It doesn't evaluate a company's balance sheet, the development of its revenue pipeline, the health of its industry, the price of its stock, its debt load, etc. It performs none of this due diligence. Yes it is cheap, as it should be. On its 42nd birthday this past August, it posted a lifetime average annual return of 11.18%. If you had invested $10,000 on opening day and left it alone, it would have grown to $857,275.

title: In Defense of SEC Settlement Gag Clauses
summary: Such a settlement which must be mutually agreed is without any usable legal factual finding having been made or agreed to.. Your editorial "Shut Up, the SEC Explained" (Jan. 18) criticizes the requirement that targets of the Securities and Exchange Commission who choose to settle enforcement proceedings are precluded as a part of the settlement from publicly denying the allegations of the complaint. To balance this, the settlement which must be mutually agreed is without any usable legal factual finding having been made or agreed to. If there was a legal determination that the defendant violated securities laws, the defendant would thereafter be barred in any shareholder suit from denying what a trier of fact has concluded. This could spell trouble for defendants of shareholder proceedings who would be stopped from relitigating violations alleged in the SEC's complaint.

title: The Constitution Is Very Clear About Religious Tests
summary: Senate Confirmation questions that have the sense of: "Since you are a Catholic" aren't only inappropriate but unconstitutional.. Michael Keegan, president of People for the American Way, couldn't have been more wrong in his response ("Senators Were Right to Ask Those Questions on Religion," Letters, Jan. 16) to the Jan. 3 "Kamala Harris's Dark Knights" editorial. The same Article VI of the Constitution that prohibits religious tests for any office also requires that "The Senators and Representatives before mentioned . . . shall be bound by Oath or Affirmation to support this Constitution." The wording in plain English is clear and not at all ambiguous. "This Constitution" means the one currently in effect and not some personal desired version. With those facts established, questions that have the sense of "Since you are a Catholic . . . ," aren't only inappropriate but unconstitutional.

title: The New Branding Strategy: Churn Out 'Content'
summary: Co-opting the tools of traditional journalism, brands from Red Bull to Ralph Lauren have refashioned themselves into content-creating machines. SO FAR THIS MORNING, I've scrolled past tweets from Taco Bell, GQ Magazine and Lowe's Home Improvement; I've read an article about luxury luggage on the website of Ssense, a Montreal-based retailer; and I've "liked" Instagram posts by Belgian label Dries Van Noten and Patagonia. It's not even 10 a.m., and I've already consumed a whopping dose of "content." Content, these days, is the catchall term for all the media that we consume, both traditional and brand-generated. Tweets are content. Articles are content. Instagram posts are definitely content. Streaming TV shows or movies can also be considered content. "Somebody the other day called the word 'content' a 'suitcase word,'" said Yale Breslin, a 33-year-old self-professed "content creator" who has worked at advertising agencies and magazines in New York. By referencing luggage, said Mr. Breslin, his colleague meant that, "No one really knows what it is anymore-it just holds anything."

title: China Civil-Rights Lawyer Sentenced to 4½ Years in Prison for Subversion
summary: Wang Quanzhang was one of the many lawyers and legal activists detained during a government crackdown in 2015. A Chinese court found a combative civil-rights lawyer guilty of subversion and sentenced him to 4½ years in prison, the final prosecution from a sweeping government crackdown against legal activists.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: U.S. Removes Rusal From Sanctions List
summary: Relief for pro-Putin oligarch's company cheers metal markets, angers Democrats who call Trump too easy on Russia. WASHINGTON-The Treasury Department on Sunday removed Russian aluminum company Rusal from its sanctions list after a blacklisted billionaire and close ally of President Vladimir Putin, Oleg Deripaska, delivered on a promised plan to divest his majority ownership stake, the office said.

title: Paul Weiss Breaks Into Supreme Court Work With a New Partner
summary: Kannon Shanmugam will help build an appeals practice at the New York-based firm known for its litigation and mergers and acquisitions work. An elite New York law firm is poised to break into the rarified world of U.S. Supreme Court work with the hire of a lawyer with exceptional experience in that area.

title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Philippine Attack That Killed at Least 20
summary: Attack occurs days after voters overwhelmingly backed self-rule and ratified a peace deal between the government and mainstream separatists. Twin explosions at a Roman Catholic cathedral in the southern Philippines killed at least 20 people in a bloody demonstration of remaining extremist threats in a Muslim-majority region where voters last week overwhelmingly backed self-rule and ratified a peace deal between the government and mainstream separatists.

title: U.S. Pension Insurer Slams Lampert Bid for Sears
summary: Hedge-fund operator's offer for chain would leave $1.7 billion pension costs unfunded, agency says. The planned sale of Sears Holdings Corp. to its chairman, Edward Lampert, is under fire from the U.S. government's pension insurer over a $1.7 billion funding gap that the agency says should sink his efforts to buy out the chain.

title: Trump Skeptical He Would Accept Any Congressional Border Deal
summary: The president in an interview says he doubts lawmakers will find a resolution in coming weeks. WASHINGTON-President Trump said Sunday he doesn't believe congressional negotiators will strike a deal over border-wall funding that he could accept and vowed that he would build a wall anyway, using emergency powers if need be.

title: Brazil Searching for Hundreds Missing After Dam Collapse
summary: The rushing wall of mud, enough to fill a football stadium more than six times, has already claimed 58 lives. BRUMADINHO, Brazil-The dam was the size of a 28-story building and it gave way with a loud boom followed by a tidal wave of mining waste that wiped a nearby village away, leaving Brazilian authorities on Sunday still searching for hundreds of missing people two days after the collapse.

title: Roger Stone Says He Would Consider Cooperating With Mueller
summary: The longtime Trump ally was arrested Friday on charges including lying to Congress. Roger Stone, a longtime political adviser to President Trump who was arrested Friday on accusations of lying to Congress, said he would discuss cooperating with special counsel Robert Mueller if asked.

title: Maduro Demands Military's Loyalty After Attaché Defects
summary: Venezuelan president presses soldiers a day after officer in U.S. recognizes Guaidó as legitimate head of state; 'are you coup plotters?'. CARACAS, Venezuela-President Nicolás Maduro demanded the loyalty of Venezuelan soldiers a day after the military's attaché in the U.S. broke with the authoritarian regime and recognized opposition leaderJuan Guaidó as the legitimate head of state.

title: After Abortion Vote, Progressives Remind Lawmakers They Are Watching
summary: Groups say they will support primary challenges against incumbents they believe aren't progressive enough. The same activists who pushed Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez into office and helped oust members of the state Senate's former Independent Democratic Conference have a message for lawmakers: We're still watching.

title: Superbug From India Spread Far and Fast, Study Finds
summary: Researchers find a gene first discovered in bacteria from India 8,000 miles away in the Arctic, raising fears about the global reach of antibiotic-resistant bugs.
